results.title: Textile technician
results.creator_credit: Mutual Film Corporation and Career Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”
Complex machinery is necessary at the various levels of textile manufacture. Follows the raw cotton through the spinning mill as it is processed into yarn. Then to the knitting mill, where yarn is woven into knitted garments. In the weaving mill, entirely different processes are carried out by different machines. Throughout the film, textile technicians are seen servicing this specialised machinery, some of which can tie the ends of broken yarn together again.

results.title: Summer school in Singapore
results.brief_description: As part of the Colombo Plan thirty-five students from Cambodia and Laos were invited by the United Kingdom Government to attend a summer-school in Singapore for a six-week course in the English language. The school was held in the University of Malaya and the students came from varied walks of life - government officials, teachers and high-school students. Emphasis was laid on conversational English, its rhythm, pronunciation and vocabulary.

results.title: Struggle
results.creator_credit: Peter Baroutis, Dale Butler, Keith Morris and Eureka Films
results.brief_description: In an effort to salvage some land for recreational and park use in 1971, the residents of North Carlton, an inner suburb of Melbourne, came into opposition with the building contractor representing Kimberley-Clark Australia Pty Ltd. The company had proposed plans for building a warehouse for Kleenex products on the site. Unions joined forces with the residents against the building contractor, and the film shows some of those involved voicing their opinions and how events developed during the conflict. The confrontation leads to speeches, shouting, strong language, demonstrations and some violence and the increasing involvement of progressive Trade Unions in matters other than the bread-and-butter struggle. Suitable for secondary school level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Baroutis, Dale Butler, Keith Morris and Eureka Films

results.title: Think back: an introduction to safe and efficient patient transfer and object handling
results.creator_credit: Phil Fury, Geoff Crane and Australia. Repatriation Dept.
results.brief_description:
This 1975 film, commissioned by the Australian Repatriation Department, provides instruction on the correct methods of manual handling in order to avoid back injury. The film contains three distinct sections: the first focusing on the principles for lifting heavy objects; the second showing different methods for lifting patients in the hospital; and the third showing methods for manoeuvring heavy loads such as shovelling material and pushing a trolley.

The first section includes animated sections showing the anatomy of the spine and the different types of back injury, including slipped disks, muscle and ligament strain. It then outlines the steps for lifting a heavy load, focusing on a truck driver loading various objects onto the tray of his vehicle.

The second section is directed at hospital staff, as an instructional video for lifting patients correctly. It shows methods of lifting patients up in bed, into a wheelchair and into a bath. Of particular note is the athletic wear (leotards and tracksuits) of the period worn by the nurses and patients in the demonstrations.

The third section shows methods of manual handling in everyday life with correct posture and stability, including shovelling material; pushing a trolley; and lifting a box into the back seat of a car.

A Repatriation Commission Film
Consultant: David Ferguson, Associate Professor in occupational health, the University of Sydney

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Dream
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description: A partly animated film based on a series of drypoint prints (‘Movements’ and ‘Combats’) by Australian printmaker Charles Lloyd on the theme of aggression in society. The sound composition by Arthur Cantrill is a mix of percussion and altered piano (plucking and hitting strings and soundboard, played by Arthur Cantrill), sound effects (including breathing), and electronically modified children’s laughter, recorded on a Nagra reel to reel tape recorder and transferred to 16mm magnetic tracks which were laid and mixed in a professional sound studio, where reverberation was added to some sections.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films

results.title: WCSC
results.brief_description:
Tune in as Jerry and Bruce commentate the sports event of the millennium! Rushkov versus Javichenko. Be sure to experience the giddying highs of Friday night WCSC live at Viagro Stadium.
Animated work. Includes animated nudity. Voices - Trent Baker, Simon Philamon. Written, directed and animated by Michael Hill.

results.title: Tree of us
results.creator_credit: Vilakone Phachanthavong and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
Vilakone has created powerful graphics in this animated work about the family of the future through the use of a predominantly red background, with black and white hand-drawn images. No dialogue.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.

results.title: The Urban migration
results.creator_credit: James Paul and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
This rather grim story in black and white of urbanisation versus nature uses cut-out and hand-drawn animation. No dialogue.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.
